@graph.citation: Jefferson Parish Hospital Dist. No. 2 v. Hyde, 466 U. S. 2 (1984)
@graph.reasoning: The Government has granted the seller a patent or similar monopoly over a product, it is fair to presume that the inability to buy the product elsewhere gives the seller market power.

@graph.citation: United States v. Loew’s Inc., 371 U. S. 38 (1962)

@graph.reasoning: Amended the Patent Act to eliminate the market power presumption in patent misuse cases.

@graph.citation: Trident, Inc. v. Independent Ink, Inc., 547 U. S. 28 (2006)
@graph.involvedParties: Petitioners: Trident, Inc., and its parent, Illinois Tool Works Inc.; Respondent: Independent Ink, Inc.
@graph.reasoning: Whether the presumption of market power in a patented product should survive as a matter of antitrust law despite its demise in patent law.

@graph.citation: International Salt Co. v. United States, 332 U. S. 392 (1947)
Henry v. A. B. Dick Co., 224 U. S. 1 (1912)
@graph.reasoning: Unpatented ink was the product that was “tied” to the use of a patented product through the use of a licensing agreement.
